subject: Re: [junit] Re: Test Grouping/Partitioning
msgSnippet: ... What would be interesting is to know *why* they classified their tests in that way. Do you have some insights into that? ... Of course we all know that
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> Hi Kent,
>
> Here are a few other classifications I've seen TestNG users use these past
> years:
>
> - Test type: unit, functional, integration, system, acceptance,
> performance.
> - Test size: small, medium, large.
> - Functional description: web, gui, html, jsp, servlet, database,
> back-end.
> - Speed of the test: slow, fast.
> - Procedural: check-in, smoke-test, milestone, release.
> - Platform: os.win32, os.linux, os.mac-os
> - Hardware: single-core, multi-core, dual-cpu, memory.1gig, memory.
> - Runtime schedule: week-days, weekends, nightly, monthly

What would be interesting is to know *why* they classified their tests
in that way. Do you have some insights into that?

> About your Assurance/CPU point: in my experience, CPU very quickly stops
> being the bottleneck for functional tests.
>
> Network bandwidth, I/O throughput, environment setup and test data
> initialization or uninitialization are what takes most of the time of
> lengthy tests as your application grows. And as I said before, test runs
> that take hours if not sometimes entire nights to run are pretty common in
> enterprise software.

Of course we all know that common != inevitable.

I'm not sure I need JUnit to support common behavior. What I really want
it to support is excellent behavior. Might just be me, of course.

Cheers, Ilja
